column1: The Château de Maisons (now Château de Maisons-Laffitte)
column2: designed by François Mansart from 1630 to 1651
column3: is a prime example of French baroque architecture and a reference point in the history of French architecture. The château is located in Maisons-Laffitte

column3: had been in possession of part of the seigneurie of Maisons since 1460

column11: but works on the outbuildings continued after that date. Louis XIV visited Maisons in April 1651.

column1: The attribution to François Mansart was common knowledge among contemporaries. Charles Perrault reported its reputation: "The château of Maisons
column2: of which he [Mansart] had made all the buildings and all the gardens
column3: is of such a singular beauty that there is not a curious foreigner who does not go there to see it
column4: as one of the finest things that we have in France." Nevertheless

column4: and then in succession to the  marquise de Belleforière

column6: to the Parisian banker Jacques Lafitte. Starting in 1834
column7: Lafitte proceeded to develop the surrounding park as building lots; he tore down the fine stables to furnish construction materials for the purchasers. After his daughter the princesse de la Moskowa sold the château in 1850
column8: it passed to M. Thomas de Colmar
column9: and to the painter William Tilman Grommé

column11: enclosing the severely reduced space with a wrought iron grille brought from the Château de Mailly in Picardy. Grommé died in 1900. In his last will
column12: he ordered his whole property to the city of Vyborg
column13: which decided to keep his art collection but sell the château.

column2: the State purchased the château to save it from demolition. It was classed a monument historique in 1914.

column1: The Château de Maisons was built between the Seine and the forest of Saint-Germain-en-Laye
column2: with its garden front oriented to the southeast. Originally it comprised the garden
column3: a small park of 33 hectares and a large outer park of 300 hectares. The visitor arrived by one of two avenues that crossed in a T intersection before the gate to the cour d'honneur The principal central axis led to the forest
column4: the cross axis through the village to the southwest and to the river
column5: thence on to Paris. Three gateways stood at the far ends of the avenues.

column1: On one side and the other of the avant-cour
column2: Mansart constructed the stables
column3: masterworks of architecture whose monumental character gave a preview of those that would be built at Versailles and Chantilly. Of these works there exists only a grotto
column4: that served also to water the horses.

column1: The château stood on a rectangular platform outlined in the French manner with a dry moat. The cour d'honneur was defined by terraces. The central block extends symmetrically into short wings
column2: composed of several sections
column4: with raked roofs and tall chimney stacks
column6: with a broken façade reminiscent of the planning in work of Pierre Lescot and Philibert Delorme in the preceding century.  The single pile construction typical of its epoch carries three storeys
column7: a basement supporting a ground floor and piano nobile with three attic floors above.

column1: The grand central entrance vestibule of stone was originally enclosed by exceptionally fine wrought iron grilles
column2: which are today at the Louvre. Large bas-reliefs of The Seasons were executed by Gilles Guérin after drawings provided by Jacques Sarazin
column3: who oversaw all the sculpture provided for Maisons. There are lunettes representing The Elements
column4: for which Sarazin's drawings also survive. This vestibule gives onto two state apartments. The apartment on the left
column5: called the Appartement des Captifs was that of René de Longueuil; it has retained its original decor. The chimneypiece of the corner room
column6: the chambre de parade represents a bas-relief medallion of Louis XIII supported by captives and a frieze of the triumph of Louis XIII
column7: works of Gilles Guérin that have given a name to the suite of rooms.

column2: called the Appartement de la Renommée was entirely redecorated by Bélanger for the comte d'Artois in a discreet neoclassical style quite in keeping with the general classic style of the château.

column1: The staircase was of a type that Mansart originated at Balleroy
column2: in which the central space is left open
column3: so that the flights climb the four walls.
